t: Job 19
Job’s Reply to Bildad
Then*p Job answered:
How*pn long will you torment me and*ln crush me with words?
You*ln have humiliated me ten times now, and*ln you mistreat me without shame.
Even*ln if it is true that I have sinned, my*ln mistake concerns only me.
If*ln you really want to appear superior to me and*ln would use my disgrace as evidence against me,
then*ln understand that it is God who has wronged me and*ln caught me in his net.
I*ln cry out, “Violence!” but get no response; I*ln call for help, but there is no justice.
He*ln has blocked my way so that I cannot pass through; he*ln has veiled my paths with darkness.
He*ln has stripped me of my honor and*ln removed the crown from my head.
He*ln tears me down on every side so that I am ruined. He*ln uproots my hope like a tree.
His*ln anger burns against me, and*ln he regards me as one of his enemies.
His*ln troops advance together; they*ln construct a ramp against me and*ln camp around my tent.
He*ln has removed my brothers from me; my*ln acquaintances have abandoned me.
My*ln relatives stop coming by, and*ln my close friends have forgotten me.
My*ln house guests and female servants regard me as a stranger; I*ln am a foreigner in their sight.
I*ln call for my servant, but he does not answer, even*ln if I beg him with my own mouth.
My*ln breath is offensive to my wife, and*ln my own family finds me repulsive.
Even*ln young boys scorn me. When*ln I stand up, they mock me.
All*ln of my best friends despise me, and*ln those I love have turned against me.
My*ln skin and my flesh cling to my bones; I*ln have escaped with only the skin of my teeth.
Have*ln mercy on me, my friends, have mercy, for*ln God’s hand has struck me.
Why*ln do you persecute me as God does? Will*ln you never get enough of my flesh?
I*pn wish that my words were written down, that*ln they were recorded on a scroll
or*ln were inscribed in stone forever by*ln an iron stylus and lead!
But*ln I know that my Redeemer lives, and*ln at the end he will stand on the dust.
Even*ln after my skin has been destroyed, yet*ln I will see God in my flesh.
I*ln will see him myself; my*ln eyes will look at him, and not as a stranger. My*ln heart longs within me.
If*pn you say, “How will we pursue him, since*ln the root of the problem lies with him?”
then*ln be afraid of the sword, because*ln wrath brings punishment by the sword, so*ln that you may know there is a judgment.
